title: Will negotiations on a China-Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) free trade agreement be completed before 1 October 2017?
preds: Although China is ambitiously seeking to expand it's economic and military interests abroad the current Qatari blockade is causing some frustration. Coupled with North Korean tensions, and South China sea disputes, it's unlikely that the negations will be completed soon.

This is very unlikely to happen before October 2017 due to the current tensions in the GCC internally. The currrent dispute between Qatar and the rest of the GCC makes it very unlikely that a negotiation round for the free trade agreement is at the top of the agenda for the GCC countries. However, China is very eager to continue talks as this article shows:
http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-05/16/c_136288477.htm
A deal might be possible as China pushes forward with its OBOR and other initiatives but the current intra-council conflict will make it more likely that China will wait for the dust to settle.
Several members of the GCC have cut ties with Qatar over alleged support for Iran and radical Islamist groups.  This has made negotiations difficult for China.

UK-GCC FTA negotiations have been put on hold amid Qatar-GCC rift, I expect the same has happened with China. (http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/uk-gcc-trade-talks-halted-following-gulf-crisis-893229378)
Maintaining forecast. The FTA won't be signed within 2 months.

Latest news I have is https://dailynewsegypt.com/2017/07/17/china-involved-gulf-crisis/. Saudi Arabia is in an embargo with Qatar, and there are strained relationships between Iran and the Gulf Coast states, which would all be in the same agreement. Getting Qatar and Saudi Arabia and Iran in the same agreement looks like it won't happen this year.

https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/94328173/terence-obrien-changing-winds-of-strategy "The Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) is in a state of disarray over a dispute led by Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates (UAE) with Qatar over its ties with Iran and for funding terrorism. Given evidence of Saudi Arabia's own record, this last charge against Qatar is a bit rich. A collateral target shared with Egypt, is suppression of the al Jazeera broadcaster based in Qatar – the only independent media voice in the Arab region. "The broader point is that a Sunni Muslim coalition fashioned around the GCC is shaping to confront Shia Islam Iran. US President Donald  Trump's recent visit to the region helped to energise the process. . . .

China calls for faster free trade negotiation with GCC Xinhua (2017) May 16, states that: Chinese Vice President Li Yuanchao on Tuesday called on China and the Gulf Cooperation Council to speed up free trade agreement (FTA) negotiation.
Li made the remarks when he met with Kuwaiti Minister of the Amiri Diwan Affairs Sheikh Nasser Sabah Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah, who led a delegation to the just-concluded Belt and Road Forum for International Cooperation in Beijing.
Li said China and Kuwait should take advantage of the Belt and Road Initiative to promote cooperation in energy, finance, and industrial parks.
The Kuwaiti minister congratulated China on the success of the forum, saying Kuwait is willing to deepen cooperation with China in various fields.
The GCC includes Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. China and the bloc first started FTA talks in 2004 but efforts stalled after five years. Negotiation reopened in 2016 (para. 1-5). Xinhua Net Website. (2017). China calls for faster free trade negotiation with GCC. Xinhua. Retrieved from
http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-05/16/c_136288477.htm
Given Qatar crisis (which is really a Gulf majority embargo on natgas exports to China), likelihood of a regional agreement this year is very low.
The GCC is closer to breaking up instead of negotiating new agreements.

A China-GCC free-trade agreement has long been in the works, and it is expected to be signed in the next year
https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2017/06/21/how-china-is-shifting-toward-the-middle-east/ With no progress on concluding rounds, even next year now seems optimistic.

Lowering to 0%. Can’t see the FTA being signed within 3 months given the current situation with the GCC and as @tsm said, the 19th National Congress of the Communist Party of China is expected to take place in October/November 2017 - which will take precedence over the FTA.
There are no news on this issue at all.
The Qatar Crisis making cooperation difficult. Plus, I haven't seen any news on the subject in a while.
Row between Qatar and Saudi probably stops this

Lowering my forecast due to the diplomatic crisis with Qatar. The sino-GCC free trade agreement will probably not move on until the GCC has resolved it's issue with Qatar, or Qatar is excluded from the GCC.
Due to issues with Qatar, most GCC related agreements will be put on hold for the next 9-16 months

Third week of the ‘Qatar Crisis’:  "Qatari's ambassador to the US accused the U.A.E. and Saudi Arabia of committing the same sins they're boycotting his country for." Sheik Meshal bin Hamad Al Thani said, in an opinion piece for the Wall Street Journal: "The U.A.E. was singled out in the 9/11 Commission’s report for its role in laundering money to terrorists" (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-06-19/qatar-reminds-gulf-critics-of-9-11-as-crisis-enters-third-week)  An article on LA Times reported the Qatari Foreign Minister, Sheik Mohammed bin Abdulrahman al Thani, saying: “Qatar is willing to sit and negotiate about whatever is related to gulf security” (http://www.latimes.com/world/middleeast/la-fg-qatar-explainer-2017-story.html). He also said “Qatar supports Kuwaits efforts to mediate the crisis, but warned that Qatar’s foreign policy would not be open to negotiate”  Meanwhile, Reuters reported UAE Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Anwar Gargash, stating “that those seeking to isolate Qatar had no intention of backing down unless their demands were met…Qatar will realise that this is a new state of affairs and isolation can last years” (http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-gulf-qatar-idUKKBN19A1BS)  Appears to be a lot of posturing and no constructive dialogue, therefore lowering my forecast as this rift will continue to put the FTA on hold.

Wild card!  Dateline June 21, 2017 -- King Salman of Saudi Arabia promoted his 31-year-old son, Mohammed bin Salman, to be next in line to the throne on Wednesday, further empowering a young, activist leader at a time when the kingdom is struggling with low oil prices, a rivalry with Iran and conflicts across the Middle East. The decision to remove the previous crown prince, Mohammed bin Nayef, 57, comes as some members of the royal family have chafed at the rise of the younger prince, who emerged from relative obscurity when his father, 81, ascended the throne in January 2015.  -- https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/21/world/middleeast/saudi-arabia-crown-prince-mohammed-bin-salman.html @sevedb @Anneinak @Iainhen99 @Khalid @tsm @Rene @JS What do you make of this development?
It just seem prudent to lower the probabilities for this to happen now.

Relations between Qatar and other GCC members do not seem to be improving, with the UAE and Bahrain imposing a ban on sympathising with Qatar:
"Abu Dhabi said violations are punishable up to 15 years in jail and a fine of at least $136,000, local media reported" (http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/bahrain-detains-citizen-sympathising-qatar-agency-reports-458828410). 
The United Nations Human Rights Chief,  Zeid Ra'ad al-Hussein, said: "I am also extremely troubled to hear that the UAE and Bahrain are threatening to jail and fine people who express sympathy for Qatar or opposition to their own governments’ actions, as this would appear to be a clear violation of the right to freedom of expression or opinion." (http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/uns-zeid-warns-gulf-states-respect-rights-qatar-row-399029839) 
This rift could take at least a few months to resolve, with both Qatar and Saudi Arabia refusing to budge, leading me to lower forecast due to the time frame.

http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-05/16/c_136288477.htm "BEIJING, May 16 (Xinhua) -- Chinese Vice President Li Yuanchao on Tuesday called on China and the Gulf Cooperation Council to speed up free trade agreement (FTA) negotiation." COMMENT: Clearly, things aren't moving as fast as the Chinese would like. The 10th round of negotiations that was supposed to be held at the end of March 2017 has yet to happen, with apparently no official explanation.
At the moment there is not so much cooperation in the Gulf.  Until this gets sorted, the GCC is not likely to turn its collective attention to trade deals.

Lowering forecast: With the UAE, Saudi Arabia and Bahrain cutting diplomatic relations with Qatar; and Oman and Kuwait being the only GCC nations to maintain ties, this will surely have an impact on the timeline for the FTA to be signed. If the GCC isn't united, then doing some sort of deal as a group will certainly be hindered by this news. 
(http://edition.cnn.com/2017/06/05/middleeast/saudi-bahrain-egypt-uae-qatar-terror/index.html)

The 9th round of negotiations concluded in December 2016 with a statement that the next round would be held end March 2017. However, further negotiations have yet to be reported, which suggests an agreement within the next four months is now very unlikely.
Lowering forecast due to no negotiations so far in 2017.

Dropping thirteen  points because there hasn't been a formal negotiation session since December and FTA agreements always get delayed because of last minute problems. I haven't even found evidence that the next negotiating summit has been scheduled.

U S and Pacific Rim countries at odds in heated trade meeting Ananthalakshmi, A. & Nguyen, M. (2017). U.S. and Pacific Rim countries at odds in heated trade meeting. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-apec-vietnam-idUSKCN18H02B

The Chinese side is willing to take the visit of the King of Saudi Arabia to China as an opportunity to enhance the docking of bilateral development strategies and speed up negotiations on the China-Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) free trade area (FTA). China supports Chinese enterprises to expand investment in Saudi Arabia and carry out cooperation on projects such as industrial parks. Saudi Arabia is willing to play a positive role in the GCC FTA talks, enhance communication and cooperation between the two countries at bilateral, regional and global levels, so as to facilitate Saudi Arabia-China relations to move toward a deeper, broader and stronger direction. Adel bin Ahmed Al-Jubeir appreciates Foreign Minister Wang Yi's propositions and measures expounded at the G20 Foreign Ministers' meeting on sustainable development and partnerships with Africa.
______________________________
COMMENTS:  all talks, no substance.
"China calls for faster free trade negotiation with GCC" http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-05/16/c_136288477.htm
Lowering my prediciton, since not much progress in reaching the agreement and no information / update available in Newspaper / Government information. Getting tight before 1 October 2017.

The GCC is investigating dumping allegations on steel pipes from China. 
http://www.albawaba.com/business/gcc-launches-anti-dumping-probe-against-chinese-steel-companies-968052 However, it is also luring Chinese tourists.
https://jingdaily.com/gulf-cooperation-council-looks-to-china-for-future-tourism-growth/ I think this will take time.

Decreasing slightly on no major developments: China and the UAE said on the 2nd May, “they would expand cooperation and work towards a free trade agreement between China and GCC members.”
The UAE foreign minister expressed hope that the FTA negotiations between the GCC and China will go forward “at a time where we are seeing the new silk road moving from being a dream to a reality” (http://english.aawsat.com/theaawsat/business/uae-china-agree-complete-free-trade-gulf-states) If neither countries are saying that the FTA will be signed soon and are instead agreeing to “expand cooperation”, then I think the chances of it being signed by October are slowly diminishing.
No update of further negotiations on the Chinese government website http://fta.mofcom.gov.cn/enarticle/engcc/engccnews/201612/33922_1.html

Updating downward. Other than a few blips in a few regional papers, I found one mention in the Washington Post (https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2017/04/21/the-gulf-states-are-turning-to-asia-in-a-big-way-heres-why-it-matters/) and it didn't even mention the free trade agreement itself. Just general cooperation. This is going to drag on.
GCC launches anti-dumping probe against Chinese, but trade and tourism goes up. The former seems to be more is however troubling for negotiations.
no recent news, so this seems unlikely to be completed by Oct. 1

On this China trade Q and the other one, I am inclined to wonder whether they are holding off on completing negotations until they see just how much damage the new administration will do to the US position in such matters.  If it looks like US trade and economics policy has or will become the dog's breakfast promised by the Prez, one would not be surprised to see the PRC kick these matters into a higher gear.  Moving up a bit to express my serene confidence in the ineptitude of my government, or at least in the principle that the Chinese have some idea in mind and we don't.
Dropping forecast due to no recent news.
No progress in over an entire year!
Passage of time and little outward progress. Will probably drop quite quickly from here if nothing new emerges.

It’s possible that FTA negotiations haven’t grown as cold as it seems right now:  An article on the China Daily website quoted the Chinese Vice-Minister of Commerce, Wang Shouwen: “China will accelerate negotiations for a free trade agreement with the Gulf Cooperation Council for the Arab states of the Gulf this year, which certainly will offer more business opportunities between China and Saudi Arabia…The two sides are now expected to exchange views on key FTA issues such as trade conditions, rules of origin, technical barriers to trade and economic and technological cooperation”. (http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/business/2017-03/20/content_28608392.htm). 
I am skeptical that both sides can come to an agreement on these topics by October 1st 2017, so I’m lowering my forecast slightly.  In a press conference at the Ministry of Commerce on the 23rd March 2017, Spokesman Sun Jiwen spoke about the recent visit from King Salman: 
“During the visit, leaders of both sides held important meetings, reached extensive consensus on topics concerning energy, capacity cooperation, space flight, science and technology, and China-GCC FTA negotiations”. He later goes on to say both sides have agreed to “jointly enhance China-GCC FTA negotiations” (http://english.mofcom.gov.cn/article/newsrelease/press/201703/20170302540791.shtml)  However, we had this same dialogue between the GCC and China last year, where both sides were saying an agreement would be signed by the end of 2016…
Appears CNY/USD thesis was false, defaulting to 1-month TFIF ~29%.
I don't find any information about the missed deadline for a meeting at the end of March nor much detail about what needs to be done to wrap up. Negotiations seem to be dragging.

Gulf Cooperation Council European Commission Website. (2017) European Commission Website. (2017). Gulf Cooperation Council. European Commission. Trade. Retrieved from
http://ec.europa.eu/trade/policy/countries-and-regions/regions/gulf-region/
News on this Arab Strategy Forum Challenge: http://www.emirates247.com/news/government/arab-strategy-forum-calls-for-nationals-to-forecast-future-challenges-2017-04-02-1.650668

Reducing from 65% as there is no news of the negotiations that were supposed to take place at the end of March, according to the press release dated 26 December 2016. Still six months left, but it's beginning to look like this will drag on. http://fta.mofcom.gov.cn/enarticle/engcc/engccnews/201612/33922_1.html "Both sides agreed to hold the next round of negotiation at the end of March 2017. " "
Lowering slightly due to no news on FTA negotiations.
Passage of time and yet no concrete progress at all! 2019 even seems a stretch at the Sheikh's leisurely progress.

I do not think an agreement is likely within the time frame because trade talks seem to only now be entering the final phase. One reason trade deals take so long is that tough decisions are left to the very end and that means most trade deals have a long tail of issues that are much more intractable than earlier parts of an agreement. The most recent press release implied that three of the fifteen chapters still need a lot of work.  There should be a negotiation round happening around now (end of March) so we will see if a major breakthrough is announced.

Keeping my forecast at 57% for now. The China FTA Network stated that “both sides agreed to hold the next round of negotiation at the end of March 2017” (http://fta.mofcom.gov.cn/enarticle/engcc/engccnews/201612/33922_1.html). It is possible, in the next week, that we will hear some news of when this meeting will occur or in a few weeks they will update the China FTA network with the outcome of the meeting.  Saudi Arabia’s King Salman was in Beijing last week and “oversaw the signing of deals worth $65 billion on the first day of the visit” (reuters.com). The fact that Saudi Arabia have made deals on this scale with China, given the current global political climate, suggests that Saudi Arabia will be an advocate within the GCC states to sign an FTA soon - regardless of the posturing between Iran and the US. 
I stated in a previous forecast that Iran might have a role in the timeline of the FTA, however it seems that both countries are willing to brush Iran to the side, albeit slightly, to focus on what they want. “For Saudis, the forging of closer ties with Beijing is probably a way of adding a major ally against Tehran and defender of Riyadh’s interests in the region. For the Chinese, however, this will hardly be the case..China simply has its own agenda, which is often at odds with that of Riyadh’s other major ally, the US.” (http://oilprice.com/Energy/Energy-General/Is-China-The-Next-Key-Influencer-In-The-Middle-East.html). The Saudis are key influencers in the GCC, so the recent moves made by Saudi Arabia will be encouraging for the FTA to be signed this year. Whether it will be done by October is dependent on how much detail there is left to fill in with the final 6 topics.
The King is visiting Beijing, till this weekend; a year after the chairman visited him.

Lowering my forecast for the moment. Given that the GCC and China now have 7 months to sign an agreement, and the US has been taking steps to annoy China which might serve as a distraction from the FTA.  I think that Iran comes into this, in terms of what might influence the relationship between the GCC and China. The US and Iran and the US and China are continually making provocative actions and statements towards each other which I think means we could see China and Iran improving relations. “President Xi Jinpin’s visit to the Middle East last year saw the signing of billions of dollars’ worth of agreements with Saudi Arabia and a ten-fold expansion of trade with Iran over the next 10 years. The significance may go far beyond commerce as Chinese interests align more with Iranian interests than those of Saudi Arabia” (http://www.scmp.com/week-asia/geopolitics/article/2075774/what-saudi-king-salman-wants-his-tour-china-malaysia).  The Saudi King Salman will be visiting China imminently, though no date has been given, which China is planning to use as an opportunity to talk to the King about improving relations between Saudi Arabia and Iran. “We hope that Saudi Arabia and Iran can resolve the problems that exist between them via equal and friendly consultations. Chinese foreign minister Wang said at his annual news conference on the sidelines of parliament” (http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/saudi-arabia/ahead-of-king-s-visit-china-hopes-saudi-iran-can-resolve-problems-1.1990244) 
Somehow I don’t think Saudi Arabia will do that because China says they should… The Trump administration hasn’t made clear what relationship they will have with the GCC, but a good relationship is necessary for strategic positioning of US military bases for the war in Yemen, and many other security reasons.  So, if the US wants to be friends with the GCC (none of the GCC members are on the list of Trumps new travel ban), but is taking a hard line with China it could be damaging for relations

http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/1033687.shtml
"Saudi Arabia is willing to play a positive role in the China-GCC FTA talks and strengthen the country's coordination and cooperation with China on different levels."
----- Sounds like they really care....

Keeping my forecast at 60% for now. There is expected to be a 5% VAT introduced across all GCC member states in 2018 (reuters.com). Given that China is the GCC's second biggest source of imports (IMF, 2015), having a free trade agreement - which is designed to reduce trade barriers, i.e. tariffs and trade quotas - would be appealing for the GCC nations, so as to minimise the economic impact the VAT could have on businesses or consumers. This is dependent on imports from China having a VAT applied to them.
Dropping on no new news and a bit worried that behind the scenes US is working to stall this.
China has shown that it wants to get this done, and as the US pulls back on it's free trade policies other nations will turn towards China.

revised estimate :  As of January 1 2017, 147 of 225 have signed the FTA, but still have to be ratified (ie., come into force) by their respective states.  Only 68 negotiations launched.  Given the closing date of the IFP, it is unlikely that all signatories to the FTA will have completed negotiations, ratifications and implementation.

Consensus trend looks to move inverse CNYUSD (https://www.google.com/finance?q=CURRENCY%3ACNY&ei=sRGRWJmtGJCx2Aae8KvwBQ). Given .153 ~ 25% and .144 ~ 65% (±1% per .000225), CNYUSD projecting to .1454 - (.153 - .1475) ~ .140 in 8 months, 65% + (.1454 - .140) / .000225 = median probability ~89%.

No recent news on the FTA.  China appears to have trade opportunities coming its way: The executive order signed on the 23rd January for the US to withdraw from the TPP allows China to attempt to fill the void that the US has left. The Australian prime minister has said it is open to China (among other nations) to join the agreement. However, the TPP cannot go ahead without US or Japan as the deal is only ratified if 6 out of the 12 original members make up 85% of the total GDP of all 12 countries (theguardian.com). It would also take a long period of time to negotiate with new members, partly because of the complexities of the agreements, but also due to the executive order signed by President Trump on the 23rd January for notice to withdraw from NAFTA, meaning Canada and Mexico would put renegotiating NAFTA ahead of the TPP. Although the opportunity has now arisen, it would make more sense for China to put the GCC ahead of a potential TPP partnership as China already has FTA’s with 5 out of the 12 TPP member countries and has negotiations under way for a Japan-Korea FTA (Japan is a TPP member). Plus, there is the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) that has been in negotiations since 2012 and includes 7 of the 12 TPP members. (cnn.com)  The total trade between the GCC and China was worth €149,399 Mio(million) in 2015. China is the 2nd largest source of imports to the GCC and China was the GCC’s number one destination for exports (2015, IMF) (ec.europa.eu/trade)  Both countries would benefit from an agreement, though the portrayed increasing threat of Iran could cause a rift between the GCC and China, seeing as China has been investing a large amount of money in Iran (since US sanctions were lifted - most recent being $3 billion into upgrading Iran’s refining capacity - reuters.com) and Saudi Arabia’s tensions with Iran (reported that Iran supplies weapons to the Houthi rebels, the militia fighting the Saudi-backed government in Yemen - reuters.com)

These talks started in 2004.
Let that sink in. 2004. Over a decade. And now the two parties are apparently trying to sprint to the finish line. Then again, the new China-Pakistan Economic Corridor is probably going to light a fire under the Gulf States. Trade with China is becoming a must. All the cool kids are doing it. And the REALLY cool kids get to name everything “One-Something”. One China. One Belt, One Road. Singular whatevers are definitely China’s bag, man.
Still, the chances of crossing the finish line before October is slim. There is no recent news about upcoming talks, and no sign that this deal is coming to a close. I give it about half the chance the consensus does.

Trump is making it easy for China -- and others -- to look beyond the US for trade agreements. He will totally destroy whatever pacts we now have, and make new ones impossible. Therefore, China will seek to fill the void, as will Middle Eastern countries, Canada, Europe, etc. The American century is over . . . at least until we can wrest our government back out of the hands of the KKK, Nazi, extreme religious far right crazies.
next round of negotiation at the end of March 2017.  With that late a start to negotiations in 2017, there is no way this will be concluded by October.
It looks like they are on pace. Nine of 15 topics negotiated in December. Six more to go. Next meeting end of March 2017. Will update then.

With the US in running full speed from its own shadow, the PRC will move quickly to nail down some trade agreements.  They might try for TTP if they can get a few amendments.  Stay tuned; could be interesting.
American isolationism increases likelihood of deals with China by other nations.
Passage of time and slow progress, it was supposed to be completed in 2016.

Remaining topics after the Dec. 2016 round, not much different than the May round (below):
http://fta.mofcom.gov.cn/enarticle/engcc/engccnews/201612/33922_1.html The outstanding issues from the May 2016 round of negotiations are not much different than the above round.
http://fta.mofcom.gov.cn/enarticle/engcc/engccnews/201605/31820_1.html China and GCC commit to complete agreement in 2016.  GCC suspension of agreement negotiations from 2009 til 2016, seems to leave a lot of subjects to cover.
http://fta.mofcom.gov.cn/enarticle/engcc/engccnews/201601/30498_1.html

During the 3-day negotiation, both sides conducted profound negotiation on the content of leftover problems such as service trade, investment, e-commerce and trade in goods, and concluded the negotiation on chapters such as the economic and technical cooperation. So far, both sides have completed nine negotiations among fifteen topics, close to reaching consensuses on the content of three chapters such as the TBT, the articles of law and e-commerce, making positive progress in the fields such as core goods and service. Both sides agreed to hold the next round of negotiation at the end of March 2017. 
http://fta.mofcom.gov.cn/topic/engcc.shtml At current rate of progress Oct 2017 is a realistic target. 9/15 topics agree, 3 with close consensus, only 3 remaining to be concluded with 9 months left in the year.

Slight increase on previous forecast:  China’s foreign minister Wang Yi said in a speech at the ‘Opening Symposium on International Developments and China’s diplomacy’ “progress is being made in China-Gulf Cooperation Council FTA-negotiations” but gave no indication of how close they are to coming to an agreement (3rd December 2016 fmprc.gov.cn).
Both China and the GCC missed the target that they had set for themselves of signing the agreement by the end of 2016. However, it is clear that both parties are determined to sign a deal after having 4 rounds of negotiations within 2016 (March, May, October and December). 
It was stated in the summary of the 9th round of negotiations that “both sides conducted profound negotiation on the content of leftover problems” (fta.mofcom.gov.cn). With the next round of negotiations set for March 2017 it is possible that they could get 2 more rounds in by October 1st to reach consensus on the remaining topics (3 of which they are close to concluding) and tie up any loose ends - provided that there aren’t any details that would cause a major dispute.
Two parties well-renowned for playing the long game..unless Trump inadvertently gets one side or the other riled up, I don't see a China-GCC FTA this year.
October seems like too tight a deadline. Next round of negotiations set for March 2017. Reassess after.

Latest round completes 9 of the 15 chapters
Three additional chapters nearly complete, and the last three chapters reportedly cove core goods and services. The next round of negotiations is set for the end of March 2017.
https://regfollower.com/2016/12/27/the-9th-round-of-china-gcc-fta-negotiation-concluded/

2016/12/21
The 9th Round of China-GCC FTA Negotiation Held in Riyadh
Passage of time and no new announcements.

Slightly revised down from my previous forecast: One of the main factors influencing whether an FTA will be signed by October next year is the US. If the GCC member states boost relations with the US in a mutually beneficial way, and tensions between US and China remain as unstable as they look today, then it’s possible China could turn away from an FTA.  China released their first ‘Arab Policy Paper’ in January 2016, laying out their goals with the Arab nations - showing a sign of increasing negotiations between China and Middle Eastern countries to achieve what they set out to achieve 11 years ago when starting the China-Arab States Cooperation forum. So signing an FTA was looking promising.  But there are several political issues that could affect the relations between the GCC member states and China, with the US at the base of them: It was announced today that President-elect Donald Trump’s pick for head of the White House National Trade Council is the economist Peter Navarro - a fierce critic of China. Having written books on China’s economy, such as ‘Death by China’ and ‘The Coming China Wars”, it looks like US-China relations are in for a turbulent year. This would be a driving factor for China to speed up agreeing to an FTA with the GCC. 
Trump has also added to the increasing tensions with China by continuing to go ahead with the US visit from the Taiwanese president Tsai Ing-Wen. An event that “China has reportedly tried to block in the wake of a row over perceived Pro-Taiwan comments by Donald Trump” (theguardian.com) Trump’s incoming presidency is favourable to the GCC, this can be seen by the President-elects top job picks showing a desire to improve the relationship between the US and GCC member states. The US works closely with Arab partners on areas such as counter-terrorism, intelligence sharing and the war on Syria - it has also been reported that Saudi Arabia provides bases for US drone flights. (cnnpolitics.com). The appointment of Rex Tillerson, as Secretary of State, who ‘has praised Qatar as “successful” and “committed” to its people and has spoken of cooperation with Saudi Arabia and the UAE’ (middleeasteye.net), sends a positive message to the oil rich GCC member states about the oil industry and global markets. However, Trump’s appointment of David Friedman as US ambassador to Israel could have implications for Arab governments; Friedman expressed the view that Palestinians should not have their own state after calling the effort to find a solution an “illusion” (cnnpolitics.com). Saudi Arabia expressed support for the Palestine’s to have their own sovereignty, with China also taking the same view - stating in their Arab policy paper “China supports the Middle East peace process and the establishment of an independent state of Palestine…” (beltandroad.hktdc.com).

China and the Arab nations, particularly the GCC, are reliant on each other - the Arab nations have become China’s biggest crude oil supplier and the Arabs import domestic machinery, technology etc. from China. If the GCC makes a deal with the incoming US administration that China does not support (or vice versa), the FTA might be delayed.
Down from 77% on 12 November due to lack of any recent positive news.

The negotiations have accelerated and it is in both sides best interest to complete it sooner than later, particularly with the uncertainty of how international trade will operate in a Trump administration. China’s “One Belt – One Road” initiative has a real opening to move forward in the next year as the Trump administration will take time to elucidate and implement trade policies.

Apologies if this has been mentioned previously:
Given the appointment of Terry Branstad as US ambassador to China by Trump, it is a positive signal for the Chinese that the US wants to maintain and develop China-US relations - could mean China isn't in a rush to get into the Middle East. However, China has seen Trump as impulsive and are entering, what they are calling, a period of unprecedented uncertainty. 
According to a statement made on fmprc.gov.cn “Presidents Xi’s first visit to the region elevated China’s relations with Saudi Arabia and Iran to higher levels and improved Chinas strategic presence in the region… China and Saudi Arabia established a high-level committee which has convened its first meeting and produced important outcomes on energy and industrial park cooperation. Progress is being made in China-Gulf Cooperation Council FTA negotiations.”
In May this year, the FGCC Chambers Secretary General, Naqi, said “due to the positive response from both sides an FTA could be signed this year or 2017” - it is very unlikely an FTA will be signed this year given the fact that there are only 23 days left. However, both countries have a lot to gain from an FTA, with China’s main import from the GCC being fuel products and derivatives in 2014 (gulftimes.com) and China’s main exports to the GCC member states being electrical goods and machinery. 
The main drivers for China to speed up and improve relations with the Middle East, namely the GCC, is any possible impacts on US-China relations (when Trump is inaugurated) and any escalation in rivalry between the Sunnis and Shiites - as the Shiites make up the majority of the Persian Gulf and China imports over half of its crude from the Persian Gulf.

With the US preparing to slink, or storm, off the stage, the PRC will want to move quickly to take over leadership of the world trade biz.  They might well give up on a few minor sticking points of some outstanding agreements just to show they can, expecting with good reason to make it up some other way in future.

- Per ts2m's research, "The GCC idea has been floating around for 4450 days now, while successful negotiations took 700 to 3700 days." With TPP now DOA, China will redouble efforts on it's RCEP alternative (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regional_Comprehensive_Economic_Partnership), likely to the detriment of GCC negotiations.
- Similarly, Saudi Arabia's Trump anticipation rally and post-election follow through (https://www.google.com/finance?q=TASI&ei=hOY9WMHSI8fKjAGUv7iYCQ) suggests smart money expects improvement in US-Gulf (trade) relations, to the detriment of China.
- The ongoing contraction in global trade puts macro pressure on any and all global trade negotiations. Students of history are right to expect a return to autarkic policy (protectionism) and trade wars, as globalism fades.

The PRC's move to Big Dog status in many areas of endeavour will accelerate.  They will especially be hustling around to get a bunch of trade agreements concluded now that the incoming US president has announced that he won't be playing in that league any more.

US trade policy was already a shambles before the recent election.  Probably a lot worse for the foreseeable future.  Good time for the PRC to take over as free-trade meister.  They'll probably start pushing harder on this sort of thing.
A dead TPP and a trump administration pivot to more domestic energy production may accelerate the process.

It's very likely that this will happen given current climate. Securing a deal of this nature will provide stability against western uncertainty, given Trump win. With progress already this far, I believe they will be complete before 1 October 2017

On October 25, the 8th round of negotiation of China-GCC (Gulf Cooperation Council ) FTA was held in Beijing. Chinese Vice Minister of Commerce Wang Shouwen and the Coordinator of GCC and the Deputy Finance Minister of Saudi Arabia led delegations and attended the negotiation. During the 3-day negotiation, the two parties had in-depth discussion on service trade, investment, e-commerce and the remaining issues of trade in goods.
http://fta.mofcom.gov.cn/enarticle/enrelease/201610/33512_1.html

With the uncertainty of a US commitment to free trade between it and China and an increased focus on intervention in Syria under Clinton, China will be interested in pursuing other means of gaining economic and possibly political influence around the world.

The China--Australia agreement took from May 2005 until November 2014 to negotiate. This agreement has been going on for 12 years. They seem to look eager: http://english.alarabiya.net/en/perspective/analysis/2016/09/04/Tapping-the-potential-of-Gulf-China-partnership.html.  60% is a WAG.

Staying a bit below the group on this one.  I am congenitally skeptical of any number suggesting a high probability for completion of trade talks.  Leaving aside the current climate for such matters, which one hopes is ephemeral, such agreements virtually always get hung up for many months at the very end over details that are laughably arcane to anyone whose business is not directly involved in whatever the issue is.  It is always impressive how long talks can drag on because of the provisions affecting beekeepers or sponge divers.

growing trade partners; GCC wants to balance China/Iran relationship and is turning away from US.  GCC has upped trade agreements over the past several years.  i didn't find anything on the particular sticking points in the negotiation.

On one hand the turmoil in the Middle East puts trade on the back-burner, but a desire for economic benefits for both a market hungry China and GCC nations seeking to diversify and develop beyond oil, puts it in the forefront. Additionally such an agreement, even if it does not lead to immediate results, is a public relations bonus for both sides. China extends its influence and power, and the GCC shows that they are taking progressive political action.
ANy progress will depend on developments in Syria, Iraq, Iran and Turkey.

New Zealand and Saudi Arabian leaders on Thursday appeared to have overcome stumbling blocks towards a long-awaited free trade agreement between New Zealand and the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC). 
http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/1009094.shtml Looks like GCC is signing FTA's with speed now.

There are both good political and economic reasons for the GCC to conclude this urgently. 
Politically, with Iran coming out of the cold, its relations and trade with China is likely to increase over the coming years. To act as a counterveiling force, it is in the best interest of the GCC to build better ties with China. Especially since a growing sentiment of withdrawal from the west, they need to look east for partners. 
Economically, the GCC has been trying to move away from purely oil-based economies (look at several SEZs set to open in the coming years) and is suffering economically. The need to expand its economic opportunities away from purely oil and gas exporting means that a trade agreement will be higher on the agenda for the GCC.

If trump Wins election there will be urgency on Chinese to quickly diversify their trade basket.  Even if Clinton wins TPP will not be enacted in its current format and will have to be renegotiated it is in interest of China to complete GCC asap but actual speed will depend upon concessions which will depend upon US election outcome.

When trade talks are nearly done, they usually go on for quite a lot longer.  This is because the negotiators leave the really difficult items to be taken up later, at which point a lovely open-field tank battle becomes house-to-house fighting.   Odds aren't bad that this will be done in a year, but it will likely still be a hard slog; also, national leaders are easily distracted from this stuff, since it is not inherently interesting nor politically popular.  The fact that something is a good idea is not necessarily an accurate predictor of how quickly or how well it will get done, if it gets done at all.
A look into how NZ struggles with its own China-FTA: contract is contract. http://www.radionz.co.nz/national/programmes/insight/audio/201799415/insight-upgrading-the-china-free-trade-agreement

To compete globally (i.e against the US and EU) this trade agreement will need to be completed at some point. However, with the recent stuttering of TPP the impetus for a rushed agreement may be reduced. From a business perspective China Gulf negotiations have been in progress for many years, if the agreement was truly beneficial to both sides it would have been done by now. There is a strong possibility that business leaders from both regions are doing better without an agreement than they may do with one.
Completion of a GCC FTA serves all parties. It's reasonable to predict a resolution within the year.

This one is hard to call, because the China deal will be GCC's first really big FTA. So far they have only done FTAs with Syria, Singapore and EFTA (a tiny set of European markets). I think the delays, if there are any, will only come from the GCC side.

Extremely likely. China is an attractive partner for middle-eastern countries: its only goal is to trade rather than apply diplomatic pressure to change internal politics of the countries it does business with. It represents an easy source of diversification for Gulf nations, a robust buyer for their commodities, and leads the way for future integration (perhaps in defense trade). Additionally, there is little possibility of a reversed decision on either side, given their consistency in decision-making.
Renewed interest in talks and no news as of late, maybe no news is good news
China knows how to get things done, and ultimately everyone wants access to China, so probably yes.

Trade negotiations always take longer than anybody thinks they will, there doesn't seem to be any strong economic or political urgency about it; and all of these governments have other things on their minds just now anyway.  If this doesn't start to move pretty fast, it's likely to sit around a while longer.
Would somebody explain why people within merely 48 hours lost confidence in the negotiation tracks?
Time is stretching. Deal will go more slowly.
No rush here - and more strategic leverage as time drags on.

"The UAE Cabinet last week took the bold decision to grant instant visas for Chinese visitors on their arrival to the UAE. Meanwhile, Saudi Arabia signed more than 11 agreements with China related to various investment fields. These two events reflect the Gulf states’ profound understanding of the importance of restructuring their international relations in line with emerging developments and the growing power of some economies and the decline of others. For instance, the volume of trade between the UAE and China shot up from $55 billion (Dh202 billion) two years ago to $60 billion this year and expected to reach $80 billion in 2018, according to official forecasts. In this respect, the Gulf states can, through the General Secretariat, set the tune for signing free trade agreements with China and India. The two represent the UAE’s largest trade partners and make up about 40 per cent of the Gulf’s petrochemical exports."

The 6th and 7th rounds of negotiations were held in March and May of this year, and the stated intention was to conclude by the end of 2016, but I've yet to find a relatively recent FTA that concluded by the initially targeted date. However, the deadline for this question is nine months later than the end of 2016, and with both governments expressing optimism I'm starting high.  I've yet to see any reports of progress, and I suspect talks will get bogged down in details as they move forward, but both sides have autocratic forms of government so if they really want to conclude these talks I expect they will. I'll adjust my forecast as and when indications of sticking points are reported, though unlike TTIP or RCEP there are few chances of leaks so probably one will have to make a call based on anodyne official communiques.

Negotiations are an exchange of proposals and concepts; I would like to invite you to find out, together, how many meetings and negotiation rounds it takes for China to conclude FTA agreements in the past, that is the rate of progress. The Gulf and China already met seven times. I suspect that we can project from the incidence rate, how long it takes, under assumptions of mutual interest. Below are the concluded FTAs, with (imperfect) start and end dates, sorted by their durations. The GCC idea has been floating around for 4450 days now, while the successful negotiations took 700 to 3700 days, with midpoint somewhere around 3000 days. Most of them are negotiations on one degree, that is 1-on-1. There is only one other FTA with a long conceptualization phase---namely the China-India FTA. Korea	2014-Apr-28	2016-Mrz-28
Costa Rica	2008-Mai-11	2011-Aug-03
Switzerland	2012-Mai-14	2016-Apr-13
Peru 	2007-Mai-24	2012-Okt-29 Singapore 	2008-Sep-05	2015-Jan-26
Macau	2009-Mai-14	2015-Dez-07
Hong Kong	2008-Aug-02	2015-Dez-07 Australia	2008-Jun-24	2015-Dez-11
Iceland	2006-Mrz-22	2014-Jul-10
New Zealand	2006-Mrz-17	2015-Mrz-30 Chile	2005-Nov-19	2015-Mai-28
Pakistan	2006-Feb-07	2015-Nov-17
ASEAN	2005-Okt-11	2015-Dez-02 What's missing is the number of negotiation rounds.  If you simply take two countries that is closest to your place of living, we might find out faster. Should be found by Sunday (1000 GMT). I'm in Germany, so I look up the history of Switzerland and Iceland.

Negotiations are ongoing between Gulf Co-operation Council (GCC) countries and China to reach a free trade agreement, an official of the Federation of the GCC Chambers (FGCC Chambers) said.
Speaking to Gulf Times on the sidelines of a press conference at Qatar Chamber yesterday, FGCC Chambers secretary-general Abdulrahim Hasan Naqi said due to the “positive response from both sides,” a free trade agreement could be signed either this year or in 2017.
http://www.gulf-times.com/story/493544/Negotiations-ongoing-for-GCC-China-free-trade-agre

Comment: This article is quite positive on all fronts.

Given that 1. Ratification by the parties to the agreement is not required.
2. Negotiations started in 2004
3. http://fta.mofcom.gov.cn/enarticle/engcc/engccnews/201605/31820_1.html
4. ETA is 2016, the timeframe is sufficient.

On one hand it took from 2004-2009 to lay the framework of the last attempt at a GCC free trade agreement.  On the other it's mutually beneficial, with the (albeit outdated) groundwork done and originally scheduled for the end of 2016.

So little evidence in either direction! And I don't know how good a record either side has of completing trade agreements on schedule. My instinct is that a deadline like "end of 2016" is likely to be missed by 6-12 months, but that's an instinct with nothing to back it up. But the agreement having spent 12 years in the making makes me... a little pessimistic, w/r/t deadlines. I'll start *slightly* lower than the crowd, but look for reasons to move.

Trade agreements, no matter how obviously beneficial to all concerned, always take longer to wrap up than anyone thinks they're going to.  They are highly subject to the 80-20 rule:  80% of everything gets sorted in the first 20% of the time, and the residuum gets stuck for rather longer.
China will pull back so as not to further thumb its nose at U.S.

Associated with China's "One Belt one Road" Project.  Benefits for both GCC and China are available, and the Q allows a long time frame.  Geo political rivalries may interfere.
